editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The phoenix, as it hath been sundry times acted by the children of Paul's, and presented before his majesty.
London printed by E.a. for A, ay, and are to be sold at the sign of the white horse in Paul's-churchyard. 1607.

div.head: The phoenix:
div.stage: Enter the old Duke of Ferrara, nobles, proditor, Lussurioso, and Infesto, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My lords,
Know that we far from any natural pride
Or touch of temporal sway, have seen our face
In our grave counsels foreheads: where doth stand
Our truest glass, made by times wrinkled hand.
We know we're old, my days proclaim me so:
Forty-five years, I've gently ruled this dukedom,
Pray heaven it be no fault,
For there's as much disease, though not to th' eye,
In too much pity, as in tyranny.

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: Your grace hath spoke it right.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know that life
Has not long course in me, 'twill not be long
Before I show that Kings have mortal bodies
as well as subjects, therefore to my comfort,
And your successful hopes I have a son
Whom I dare boast of; —

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Whom we all do boast off,
A prince elder in virtues then in years,

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: His judgement is a father to his youth,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Ay, ay, would he were from court,

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: Our largest hopes grow in him,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: And 'tis the greatest pity noble lord,
He is untraveled,

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: 'Tis indeed my lord.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Had he but travail to his time and virtue — o he should ne'er return again.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It shall be so, what is in hope begun,
Experience quickens, travail confirms the man,
Who's else lives doubtful, and his days oft sorry,
"Who's rich in knowledge, has the stock of glory.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Most true my royal lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Some one attend our son.

sp.speaker: Infest.
sp.l: See, here he comes my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O you come well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: 'Tis always my desire my worthy father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your serious studies, and those fruitful hours
That grow up into judgement, well become
Your birth, and all our loves: I weep that you are my son,
But virtuously I weep, the more my gladness:
We have thought good and meet by the consent
Of these our nobles, to move you towards travail,
The better to approve you to yourself
And give your apter power, foundation:
To see affections actually presented,
E'en by those men that owe them, yield more profit,
I more content, then singly to read of them,
"Since love or fear, make writers partial,
The good and free example which you find,
in other countries, match it with your own,
The ill to shame the ill, which will in time,
Fully instruct you how to set in frame,
A kingdom all in pieces.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Honoured father,
With care and duty I have listened to you,
What you desire, in me it is obedience,
I do obey in all, knowing for right,
"Experience is a kingdom's better sight.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: O 'tis the very lustre of a prince,
Travail! 'tis sweet and generous,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: He that knows how to obey, knows how to reign
And that true knowledge have we found in you,
Make choice of your attendants.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Their soon chose, only this man my lord, a loving servant of mine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What none but he?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I do entreat no more,
For that's the benefit a private gentleman
Enjoys beyond our state, when he notes all,
Himself unnoted,
For should I bear the fashion of a prince,
I should then win more flattery, than profit,
And I should give 'em time and warning then
To hide their actions from me, if I appear a sun,
They'll run into the shade with their ill deeds,
And so prevent me.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: A little too wise, a little too wise to live long.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You have answered us with wisdom, let it be.
Things private are best known through privacy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stay you my elected servant.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My kind lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Duke my father has a heavy burden,
Of years upon him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My lord it seems so, for they make him stoop.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Without dissemblance he is deep in age,
he bows unto his grave, I wonder much
Which of his wild nobility it should be
(For none of his sad counsel has a voice in't)
Should so far travail into his consent,
To set me over into other kingdoms.
Upon the stroke and minute of his death?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My lord, 'tis easier to suspect them all,
Then truly to name one.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Since it is thus,
By absence, I'll obey the Duke my father,
And yet not wrong myself.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Therein my lord,
You might be happy twice.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So it shall be,
I'll stay at home, and travail;

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Would your grace
Could make that good.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I can, and indeed a prince need no travail farther than his own kingdom, if he apply himself faithfully, worthy the glory of himself and expectation of others: and it would appear far nobler industry in him, to reform those fashions that are already in his country, than to bring new ones in, which have neither true form nor fashion; to make his court an owl, city an ape, and the country a wolf, preying upon the ridiculous pride of either, and therefore I hold it a safer stern upon this lucky advantage, since my father is ne'er his setting, and I upon the Eastern hill to take my rise, to look into the heart and bowels of this dukedom, and in disguise, mark all abuses ready for reformation or punishment.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Give me but leave unfeignedly to admire you,
Your wisdom is so spacious and so honest,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
So much have the complaints and suits of men, seven, nay seventeen years neglected, still interposed by coin and great enemies, prevailed with my pity, that
I cannot otherwise think but there are infectious dealings in most offices, and foul mysteries throughout all professions: and therefore I nothing doubt but to find travail enough within myself, and experience I fear too much: nor will I be curious to fit my body to the humblest form and bearing, so the labour may be fruitful: for how can abuses that keep low, come to the right view of a prince, unless his looks lie level with them, which else will be longest hid from him, he shall be the last man sees 'em.
sp.l: For oft between King's eyes, and subjects' crimes
Stands there a bar of bribes, the under office
Flatters him next above it: he the next,
And so of most, or many, every abuse will choose a brother,
'Tis through the world, this hand will rub the other.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You have set down the world briefly my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But how am I assured of faith in thee?
Yet I durst trust thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Let my soul be lost,
sp.p: When it shall lose your secrets: nor will I only be a preserver of them, but if you so please an assister.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: It suffices:
That King stands surest who by his virtue rises
More than by birth or blood, that prince is rare,
Who strives in youth to save his age from care,
Let's be prepared away.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I'll follow your grace,
Thou wonder of all princes, precedent, and glory,
True phoenix, made of an unusual strain,
"Who labours to reform is fit to reign.
How can that King be safe that studies not
The profit of his people? See where comes
The best part of my heart, my love.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to find you, I heard newly
of sudden travail which his grace intends
And only but yourself to accompany him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You heard in that, little beside the truth,
Yet not so sudden as to want those manners,
To leave you unregarded.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I did not think, so unfashionably of you:
How long is your return?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet come to me, scarce to my lord,
Unless the Duke refer it to his pleasure,
But long I think it is not, the Duke's age,
(If not his apt experience) will forbid it.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: His grace commands, I must not think amiss, farewell

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay stay, and take this comfort,
You shall hear often from us, I'll direct
Where you shall surely know, and I desire you
Write me the truth, how my new father in law, the
Captain bears himself towards my mother,
For that marriage, knew nothing of my mind,
It never flourished in any part of my affection.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Methinks sha's much disgraced herself.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nothing so: if he be good and will abide the touch, a captain may marry a lady, if he can sail into her good will.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Indeed that's all,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: 'Tis all in all, commend me to thy breast, farewell.
So by my lords firm policy we may see,
To present view, what absent forms would be.

div.stage: Enter the captain with souldiering fellows.

sp.l: There's noble purchase captain.
Nay admirable purchase.
Enough to make us proud for ever.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Ha?
Never was opportunity so gallant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why you make me mad.
Three ships not a poop less.

sp.p: And everyone so wealthily burdened upon my manhood.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pox on't, and now am I tied e'en as the devil would have't.
Captain, of all men living I would ha' sworn thou wouldst ne'er have married.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Sfoot, so would I myself man, give me my endue, you know I ha' sworn all heaven over and over:

sp.l: That you have i'faith.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why go too then.

sp.p: Of a man that has tasted salt water to commit such a fresh trick.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why 'tis abominable I grant you now I see't:
Had there been fewer women —
And among those women fewer drabs —
And among those drabs fewer pleasing —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Then t'ad been something:

sp.p: But when there are more women, more common pretty sweet hearts, then ever any age could boast off.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And I to play the artificer and marry: to have my wife dance at home, and my ship at sea, and both take in salt water together: o lieutenant thou'rt happy, thou keepest a wench.
I hope I am happier than so captain, for a my troth she keeps me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How? is there any such fortunate man breathing? and I so miserable to live honest? I envy thee lieutenant, I envy thee, that thou art such a happy knave, here's my hand among you, share it equally, I'll to sea with you.

sp.l: There spoke a noble captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Let's hear from you, there will be news shortly.
Doubt it not captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
What lustful passion came aboard of me, that
I should marry, was I drunk? yet that cannot altogether hold, for it was four o'clock ith' morning, had it been five, I would ha' sworn it: that a man is in danger every minute to be cast away, without he have an extraordinary pilot that can perform more than a man can do: and to say truth too, when I'm abroad what can I do at home? no man living can reach so far: and what a horrible thing 'twould be to have horns brought me at sea, to look as if the devil were ith' ship: and all the great tempests would be thought of my raising, to be the general curse of all merchants: and yet they likely are as deep in as myself, and that's a comfort: oh that a captain should live to be married! nay, I that have been such a gallant salt-thief, should yet live to be married: what a fortunate elder brother is he, whose father being a ramish ploughman, himself a perfumed gentleman, spending the labouring reek from his fathers: nostrils in tobacco: the sweat of his father's body in monthly physic for his pretty queasy harlot: he sows a pace ith' country: the tailor o'ertakes him i'th city, so that often times before the corn comes to earning, 'tis up to the ears in high collars, and so at every harvest the reapers take pains for the mercers, ha! why this is stirring happiness indeed, would my father had held a plow so, and fed upon squeezed curds and onions, that I might have bathed insensuality: but he was too ruttish himself to let me thrive under him, consumed me before he got me, and that makes me so wretched, now to be shackled with a wife, and not greatly rich neither.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Captain, my husband.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Slife call me husband again, and I'll play the captain and beat you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What has disturbed you sir, that you now look so like an enemy upon me?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Go make a widower, hang thyself,
How comes it that you are so opposite
To love and kindness? I deserve more respect,
But that you please to be forgetful of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For love to you, did I neglect my state,
Chide better fortunes from me,
Gave the world talk, laid all my friends at waste.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.l: The more fool you, could you like none but me?
Could none but I supply you?
I am sure you were sued to ▪ by far worthier men,
Deeper in wealth and gentry.
What couldst thou see in me, to make thee dote so on me,
sp.p: If I know, I am a villain: what a torment's this? why didst thou marry me? you think as most of your insatiate widows, that captains can do wonders, when alas the name does often prove the better man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That which you urge, should rather give me cause to repent then yourself.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Then to that end I do't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What a miserable state am I led into?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How now sir?

sp.speaker: Seruus:
sp.l: Count Proditer is now alighted.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What, my lord: I must make much of him, he'll one day write me cuckold: 'tis good to make much of such a man, e'en to my face, he plies it hard I thank him: —
What, my worthy lord!

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I'll come to you in order captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O that's in order: a kiss is the gamut to pricksong.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Let me salute you captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My dear esteemed count, I have a life for you:

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Hear you the news?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What may it be my lord?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: My lord, the Duke's son is upon his travail to several kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: May it be possible my lord, and yet so little rumoured?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Take't of my truth, nay, 'twas well managed, things are as they are handled: but all my care is still, pray heaven he return safe, without danger captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, is there any doubt to be had of that my lord?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I by my faith captain.
Princes have private enemies, and great:
Put case a man should grudge him, for his virtues:
Or envy him, for his wisdom: why you know
This makes him lie bare breasted to his foe.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: That's full of certainty my lord, but who be his attendants?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Thence captain comes the fear, but singly attended neither (My best gladness) only by your son in law Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Is it to be believed? I promise you my lord than I begin to fear him myself, that fellow will undo him: I durst undertake to corrupt him with twelve pence over and above, and that's a small matter: has a whorish conscience, he's an inseparable knave, and I could near speak well of that fellow.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: All we of the younger house, I can tell you do doubt him much, — the ladies removed, shall we have your sweet society captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Though it be in mine own house, I desire I may follow your lordship.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I love to avoid strife,
Not many months phoenix shall keep his life.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: So, his way is in, he knows it,
We must not be uncourteous to a lord,
sp.p: Warn him our house 'twere vild: his presence is an honour, if he lie with our wives, 'tis for our credit, we shall be the better trusted, 'tis a sign we shall live ith' world: oh tempests and whirlwinds (Who but that man whom the forefinger cannot daunt, that makes his shame his living:) who but that man I say, could endure to be thoroughly married? Nothing but a divorce can relieve me: any way to be rid of her would rid my torment: if all means fail I'll kill, or poison her, and purge my fault at sea: but first I'll make gentle try of a divorce: but how shall I accuse her subtle honesty? I'll attach this lords coming to her, take hold of that: ask counsel: and now I remember, I have acquaintance with an old crafty client, who by the puzzle of suits and shifting of courts, has more tricks and starting holes, than the dizzy pates of fifteen attorneys: one that has been muzzled in law like a bear, and lead by the ring of his spectacles from office to office: him I'll seek out with haste, all paths I'll tread,
sp.l: All deaths I'll die ere I die married.

div.stage: Enter proditor with the captain's wife.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Puh, you do resist me hardly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I beseech your lordship cease in this,
sp.p: 'Tis never to be granted: if you come as a friend unto my honour and my husband, you shall be ever welcome, if not, I must entreat it —

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Why assure yourself, madam, 'tis not the fashion.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis more my grief my lord, such as myself are judged the worse for such.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Faith you're too nice, you'll see me kindly forth:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And honourably welcome.

div.stage: Enter a groom before phoenix, and Fidelio, alighting into an inn.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you're most neatly welcome.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: You're very cleanly sir, prithee have a care to our geldings.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Your geldings shall be well considered.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Considered?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sirrah, what guess does this inn hold now?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Some five and twenty gentlemen besides their beasts.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Their beasts?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Their wenches I mean sir, for your worship knows those that are udder men are beasts.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How does your mother sit?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: Very well in health I thank you heartily sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And so is my mare i'faith.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: I'll do her commendations indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Well kept up shuttlecock:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what old fellow was he that newly alighted before us?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: Who he? as arrant a crafty fellow as ere made water on horseback: some say he's as good as a lawyer, (Marry I'm sure he's as bad as a knave) if you have any suits in law, he's the fittest man for your company: has been so ▪ towards and lugged himself ▪ that he is able to afford you more knavish counsel for ten groats, then another for ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: A fine fellow: but do you know him to be a knave, and will lodge him.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p:
Your worship begins to talk idly, your bed shall be made presently; if we should not lodge knaves, I wonder how we should be able to live honestly, are there honest men enough think you in a term time to fill all the inns in the town, and as far as I can see ▪ a knave's gelding eats no more hay than an honest man's: nay thieves gelding eats less, I'll stand to't, his master
allows him a better ordinary: yet I have my eightpence day and night, 'twere more for our profit I wus, you were all thieves, if you were so contented: I shall be called for: give your worship's good morrow.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A royal knave i'faith: we have happened into a godly inn.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Assure you my l. they belong all to one church.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This should be some old busy turbulent fellow: villainous law-worm, that eats holes into poor men's causes.

sp.l: May it please your worship to give me leave?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I give you leave sir, you have your veniam, now fill me a brown toast sirrah.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Will you have no drink to't sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Is that a question in law?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Yes, in the lowest court: ith' cellar sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Let me ha't removed presently sir.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now as you were saying sir, I'll come to you immediately too.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O very well sir:

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I'm a little busy sir,
But as how sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I pray sir?
Has brought me into the court, marry my adversary has not declared yet.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non declaravit aduersarius saist thou: what a villain's that, I have a trick to do thee good: I will get thee out a prox, and make him declare with a pox to him.

sp.l: That will make him declare to his fore grief, I thank your good worship: but put case he do declare?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Si declarasset, if he should declare there,
I would be loath to stand out to the judgement of that court

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non ad iudicium, do you fear corruption? then I'll relieve you again: you shall get a Supers●diae, non molest andam; and 〈◊〉 it big her.

sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Now if it should ever come to a testificandum, what be his witnesses?

sp.l: I little fear his witnesses.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Non metuis testes? more valiant man then Orestes

sp.p: Please you sir to dissolve this into wine, ale, or beer, I come a hundred mile to you I protest, and leave all other counsel behind me.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Nay you shall always find me a sound card, I stood not ath' pillory for nothing in eighty eight, all the world knows that: now let me dispatch you sir; I come to you presenter.

sp.l: Faith the party hath removed both body and cause with a habeas corpus.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Has he that knavery? But has he put in bail above canst tell?

sp.l: That I can assure your worship, he has not.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why then thy best course shall be, to lay out more money, take out a procedendo, and bring down the cause and him with a vengeance.

sp.l: Then he will come indeed

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: As for the other party, let the audita querela alone, take me out a special supplicauit, which will cost you enough, and than you pepper him. For the first party after the procedendo you'll get costs, the cause being sound, you'll have a judgement, nunc pro tunc, you'll get a venire fancies to warn your jury, a decem tales to fill up the number, and a capias ut legatum for your execution.

sp.l: I thank you my learned counsel.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: What a busy caterpillar's this? let's accost him in that manner.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Content my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O my old admirable fellow, how have I all this while thirsted to salute thee? I knew thee in octavo of the Duke. —

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: In octavo of the Duke: I remember the year well.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: Byth' mass a lusty proper man.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: O was I?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But still in law ▪

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Still in law. I had not breathed else now, 'tis very marrow, very manna to me to be in law: I'd been dead ere this else: I have found such sweet pleasure in the vexation of others, that I could wish my years over and over again, to see that fellow a beggar, that bawling knave a gentleman: a matter brought e'en to a judgement today, as far as ere was to begin again to morrow: oh raptures I here a writ of demur, there a procedendo, here a sui surrara, there a capiendo, tricks, delays ▪ money-laws:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Is it possible old lad?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I have been a term-trotter myself any time this five and forty years, a goodly time and a gracious: in which space I ha' been at least sixteen times beggared, and got up again: and in the mire again, that I have stunk again, and yet got up again.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And so clean and handsome how?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: You see it apparently ▪ I cannot hide it from you: nay more, in foelice hora be it spoken, you see I'm old, yet have I at this present, nine and twenty suits in law.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Deliver us man!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: And all not worth forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: May it 〈…〉 cu'd?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: The pleasure of a man is all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: An old fellow and such a stinger.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
A stake pulled out of my hedge, there's one: I was well beaten I remember, that's two: I took one a-bed with my wife again her will, that's three: I was called cuckold for my labour ▪ that's four: I took another a-bed again, that's five then one called me wittol that's six: he killed my dog for barking, seven: my maid servant was knocked at that time, eight: my wife miscarried
with a push, nine, et sic de coeteris, I have so vexed and beggared the whole parish, with process, Subpoenas, and such like molestations, they are not able to spare so much ready money from a term, as would set up a new weathercock: the churchwardens are fain to go to law with the poors money.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: And I so fetch up all the men every term time that 'tis impossible to be at civil cuckoldry, within ourselves, unless the whole country rise upon our wives.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A my faith a pretty policy.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Nay an excellent stratagem: but of all I most wonder at the continual substance of thy wit, that having had so many suits in law from time to time, thou hast still money to relieve 'em.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Has the best fortune for that, I never knew him without.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why do you so much wonder at that? why this is my course: my mare and I come up some five days before a term.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A good decorum.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Here I lodge as you see amongst inns, and places of most receipt —

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Very wittily.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: By which advantage I dive into country men's causes, furnish 'em with knavish counsel, little to their profit, buzzing into their ears, this course, that writ, this office, that ultimum refugium, as you know I have words enough for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Enough a conscience i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Enough a law, no matter for conscience. For which busy and laborious sweating courtesy, they cannot choose but feed me with money, by which I maintain mine own suits: ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Why let me hug thee, caper in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p:
Another special trick I have, nobody must
know it, which is, to prefer most of those men to one attorney whom I affect best, to answer which kindness of mine, he will sweat the better in my cause, and do them the less good, take't of my word, I helped my attorney to more clients the last term than he will dispatch all his life time: I did it.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What a noble memorable deed was there?

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Now sir.

sp.speaker: Groom
sp.p: There's a kind of captain, very robustiously inquires for you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: For me? A man of war: a man of law is fit for a man of war: we have no leisure to say prayers: we both kill a Sunday mornings: I'll not be long from your sweet company.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: O no I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What captain might this be?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou angel sent amongst us, sober law.
Made with meek eyes, persuading action,
No loud immodest tongue, voiced like a virgin,
And as chaste from sale,
Save only to be heard, but not to rail.
How has abuse deformed thee to all eyes?
That where thy virtues sat, thy vices rise,
Yet why so rashly for one villain's fault ▪
Do I arraign whole man? Admired law,
Thy upper parts must needs be sacred, pure,
And incorruptible, they're grave and wise,
'Tis but the dross beneath 'em, and the clouds
That get between thy glory and their praise,
That make the visible and foul eclipse,
For those that are near to thee, are upright,
As noble in their conscience, as their birth,
Know that damnation is in every bribe,
And rarely put it from 'em: rate the presenters,
And scourge 'em with five years imprisonment,
for off ring but to tempt 'em.
Thus is true justice exercised and used,
"Woe to the giver when the bribe's refused.
'Tis not their will, to have law worse than war,
Where still the poor'st die first,
To send a man without a sheet to his grave,
Or bury him in his papers.
'Tis not their mind it should be, nor to have
A suit hang longer than a man in chains
Let him be ne'er so fastened, they least know
That are above, the tedious steps below.
I thank my time, I do.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I long to know what captain this should be:

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: See where the bane or every cause returns.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: 'Sfoot 'tis the captain my father in law, my l.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Take heed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The divorce shall rest then, and the five hundred crowns shall stand in full force and virtue.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Then do you wisely captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A way sail I, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: A lusty crack or wind go with thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: But ah!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Ha:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Remember a scrivener

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: I'll have him for thee. Why thus am I sought after by all professions; here's a weather beaten captain, who not long since new married to a lady widow, would now fain have sued a divorce between her and him, but that her honesty is his only hindrance: to be rid of which, he does determine to turn her into white money, and there's a lord his chapman has bid five hundred crowns for her already.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Or for his part, or whole in her.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Why, do she leave to sell his wife?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: His wife? I byth' mass, he would sell his soul if he knew what merchant would lay out money upon't, and some of 'em have need of one they swear so fast.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Why, I never heard of the like.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non audivisti, didst ne'er here of that trick? why Pistor a baker sold his wife tother day to a cheesemonger, that made cake and cheese: another to a cofferer: a third to a common player: why you see 'tis common: ne'er fear the captain, be has not so much wit to be a president himself: I promised to furnish him with an odd scrivener of mine own ▪ to draw the bargain, and sale of his lady, your horses stand here gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I shall be busily plunged till towards bed time, above the chin in profundis.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What monstrous days are these?
Not only to be vicious, most men study,
But in it to be ugly, strive to exceed,
Each other in the most deformed deed.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Was this her private choice? did she neglect
The presence and opinion of her friends, for this?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I wonder who that one should be,
Should so disgrace that reverend name of lord,
So loathsomely to buy adultery?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: We may make means to know.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Take courage man, we'll beget some defence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I am bound by nature.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: I by conscience — to sell his lady: indeed she was a beast to marry him, and so he makes of her, come, I'll thorough now I'm entered.

div.stage: Enter jewellers wife with a boy.

sp.speaker: I●w.
sp.p: Is my sweet knight coming, are you certain he's coming?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Certain for sooth, I am sure I saw him out of
the barber's shop, ere I would come away.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: A barber's shop, oh he's a trim knight, would he venture his body into a barber's shop, when he knows 'tis as dangerous as a piece of Ireland: oh yonder, yonder, he comes, get you back again, and look you say as I advized you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You know me mistress?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My mask, my mask.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: My sweet revenue!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: My pleasure welcome: I have got single, none but you shall accompany me to the justice of peace my fathers.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Why, is thy father justice of peace, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.p: My father! i'faith sir I, simply though I stand here a citizen's wife: I am a justice of peace's daughter.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: I love thee the better for thy birth.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: He's at thy service my sweet revenue, for thy money paid for 'em.

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.p: Why then let him run a little before I beseech thee, for a my troth he will discover us else.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: He shall obey thee, before sirrah ▪ trudge: but do you mean to lie at your fathers all night?

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: Why should I desire your company else?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: 'Sfoot where shall I lie then.

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: What an idle question's that? why do you think I cannot make room for you in my father's house, as well as in my husbands, they're both good for nothing else?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A man so resolute in valour as a woman in desire, were an absolute leader.

div.stage: Enter two suitors with the justice Falso.

sp.p: May it please your good worship master justice.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Please me and please are yourself,
That's my word.

sp.p: The party your worship sent for, will by no means be brought to appear.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: He will not, then what would you advise me to do therein?
Only to grant your worships warrant, which is of sufficient force to compel him.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: No by my faith: you shall not have me in that trap: am I sworn justice of peace, and shall I give my warrant to fetch a man against his will? why there the peace is broken, we must do all quietly, if he come he's welcome, and as far as I can see yet, he's a fool to be absent, I by this gold is he (Which he gave me this morning)
Why, but may it please your good worship. —

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I say again please me and please yourself, that's my word still.
Sir, the world esteems it a common favour, upon the contempt of the party, the justice to grant his warrant.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis so common, 'tis the worse again, 'twere the better for me 'twere otherwise.
I protest sir, and this gentleman can say as much, it lies upon my half undoing.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I cannot see yet, that it should be so — I see not a cross yet.
I beseech your worship show me your immediate favour, and accept this small trifle but as a remembrance to my succeeding thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Angels? I'll not meddle with them, you give 'em to my wife not to me.
Ay, I sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
But I pray tell me now, did the party Vina voce, with his own mouth deliver that contempt, that
that he would not appear, or did you but jest?

sp.l: Iest? No a my troth sir, such was his insolent answer

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: And do you think it stood with my credit to put up such an abuse? will he not appear says he? I'll make him appear with a vengeance Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: Does your worship call?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Draw me a strong limbed warrant for the gentleman speedily, he will be bountiful to thee: go and thank him within.
I shall know your worship hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Ay, I prithee do. Two angels one party, four another: and I think it a great spark of wisdom and policy (If a man come to me for justice) first to know his griefs by his fees, which be light and which be heavy : he may counterfeit else, and make me do justice for nothing: I like not that ▪ for when I mean to be just, let me be paid well for't: the deed so rare, purges the bribe: how now, what's the news thou art come so hastily? how fares my knightly brother?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Troth he ne'er fared worse in his life sir: he ne'er had less stomach to his meat since I knew him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Indeed he's dead sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Newly deceased I can assure your worship: the tobacco-pipe new dropped out of his mouth before I took horse, a shrewd sign: I knew then there was no way but one with him, the poor pipe was the last man he took leave off in this world, who sold in three pieces before him, and seemed to mourn inwardly, for it looked as black the mouth as my master.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would he die so like a politician, and not once write his mind to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
No I'll say that for him sir: he died in the perfect state of memory, made your worship his full and whole executor: bequeathing his daughter, and with her all
his wealth, only to your disposition.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Did he make such a godly end sayest thou? did he die so comfortably, and bequeath all to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Your niece is at hand sir, the will, and the witnesses.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: What a precious joy and comfort's this, that a justice's brother can die so well, nay in such a good and happy memory, to make me full executor. Well he was too honest to live, and that made him die so soon: now I beshrew my heart, I am glad he's in heaven, has left all his cares and troubles with me, and that great vexation of telling of money, yet I hope he had so much grace before he died to turn his white money into gold, a great ease to his executor.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: See here comes your niece my young mistress sir,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Ah my sweet niece, let me kiss thee, and drop a tear between thy lips: one tear from an old man is a great matter, the cocks of age are dry, thou hast lost a virtuous father, to gain a notable uncle.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: My hopes now rest in you next under heaven

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Let 'em rest, let 'em rest.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You're most welcome ere ye begin sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: We are both led by oath and dreadful promise,
Made to the dying man at his last sense,
First to deliver these into your hands,
The sureties and revealers of his state.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: With this his only daughter and your niece,
Whose fortunes are at your disposing set,
Uncle and father are in you both met.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Good i'faith, a well spoken gentleman, you're not an esquire sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
Not sir? more's the pity: by my faith better men than you are, but a great many worse: you see I have been a scholar in my time, though I'm a justice now: niece you're most happily welcome, the charge of you is
wholly and solely mine own: and since you are so fortunately come niece, I'll rest a perpetual widower.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I take the meaning chaster than the words:
Yet I hope well of both, since it is thus,
His phrase off ends least that's known humourous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I make my brother (Says he) full and whole executor, honestly done of him i'faith, seldom can a man get such a brother: and here again says he, very virtuously, I bequeath all to him and his disposing: an excellent fellow a my troth, would you might all die no worse, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: But as much better as might be.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Bless your uprightness master justice,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: You're most soberly welcome sir: daughter you've that ye kneel for, rise, salute your weeping cozen.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Weeping cozen?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I cozen.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Eye to weeping is very proper, and so is the party that spoke it believe me, a pretty, fine, slender, straight, delicate knit body.
sp.l: O how it moves a pleasure through our senses!
How small are women's wastes to their expenses?
I cannot see her face, that's under water yet.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: News as cold to the heart as an old man's kindness: my uncle dead?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I have lost the dearest father.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: If she marry by your consent, choice and liking make her dowry five thousand crowns: hum, five thousand crowns? therefore by my consent she shall ne'er marry, I will neither choose for her, like of it, nor consent to't.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Now by the pleasure of my blood a pretty cousin: I would not care, if I were as near kin to her, as I have been to her kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Daughter, what gentleman might this be?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No gentleman sir, he's a knight.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Is he but a knight? troth, I would a sworn had been a gentleman, to see, to see, to see.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: He's my husband's own brother, I can tell you (Sir:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thy husband's brother: speak certainly prithee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I can assure you father, my husband and he has lain both in one belly.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I'll swear then he is his brother indeed, and by the surer side: I crave hearty pardon sweet kinsman that thou hast stood so long unsaluted in the way of kindred.
sp.l: Welcome to my board: I have a bed for thee,
My daughter's husband's brother shall command,
sp.p: Keys of my chests and chambers. — I have stable for thy horse, chamber for thyself, and a loft above for thy lousy lackey, all fit, away with handkirchers, dry up eyes, at funeral we must cry: now let's be wise.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I told you his affection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It falls sweetly.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: But here I bar you from all plots tonight ,
The time is yet too heavy to be light.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Why, I'm còntent, I'll sleep as chaste as you,
And wager night by night who keeps most true.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Well we shall see your temper.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Fear not me Fidelio: become you that invisible rope-maker the scrivener, that binds a man as he walks yet all his joints at liberty, as well as I'll fit that common folly of gentry, the easy-affecting venturer, and no doubt our purpose will arrive most happily.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Chaste duty my lord works powerfully in me, and rather than the poor lady my mother should fall upon the common side of rumour to beggar her name, I would not only undergo all habits, offices, disguised professions, though e'en opposite to the temper my blood holds: but in the stainless quarrel of her reputation, alter my shape for ever.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p:
I love thee wealthier, thou hast a noble touch, and by this means which is the only safe means to preserve
thy mother from such an ugly land and sea monster as a counterfeit captain is, he resigning and basely selling all his estate, title, right, and interest in his lady, as the form of the writing shall testify.
sp.l: What otherwise can follow but to have,
A lady safe delivered of a knave?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am in debt my life, to the free goodness of your inventions.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: O they must ever strive to be so good,
"Who sells his vow is stamped the slave of blood.

div.stage: Enter captain his lady following him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Captain, my husband.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hence, we're at a price for thee, at a price, wants but the telling, and the sealing, then —

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Have you no sense, neither of my good name or your own credit?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Credit? pox of credit, that makes me owe so much: it had been better for me by a thousand royals I had lost my credit, seven year ago, t'as undone me, that's it that makes me fly: what need I to sea else, in the spring time, when woods have leaves, to look upon bald oak.
sp.l: Happier that man say I, whom no man trusts,
It makes him valiant, dares outface the prisons,
Upon whose carcase no gowned raven jets,
O he that has no credit owes no debts.
'Tis time I were rid on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O why do you so wilfully cherish your own poison? and breath against the best of life, chaste credit.
sp.l: Well may I call it chaste, for like a maid
Once falsely broke it ever lives decayed.
O captain, husband, you name that dishonest,
By whose good power all that are honest live,
What madness is it to speak ill of that,
Which makes all men speak well, take away credit
By which men amongst men, are well reputed,
that man may live, but still lives executed.
O then show pity to that noble title
Which else you do usurp: you're no true captain,
To let your enemies lead you, foul disdain,
And everlasting scandal, o believe it!
The money you receive for my good name
Will not be half enough to pay your shame.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, I'll sell thee then to the smock: see here comes my honourable chapman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O my poison!
Him, whom mine honour and mine eye abhors.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Lady, what so unjovially departed?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fine she policy? she makes my back her bolster, but before my face, she not endures him, tricks.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Captain, how haps it she removed so strangely?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O for modesty's cause awhile my lord: she must restrain herself, she's not yours yet:
sp.l: Beside, it wear not wisdom to appear,
sp.p: Easy before my sight, fah, wherefore serves modesty but to pleasure a lady now and then, and help her from suspect, that's the best use 'tis put too.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Well observed of a captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: No doubt you'll be soon friends my lord.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I think no less.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And make what haste I can to my ship, I durst wager you'll be under sail before me.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: A pleasant voyage captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, a very pleasant voyage as can be: I see the hour is ripe, here comes the prisons bawd the bond-maker, one that binds heirs before they are begotten.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: And here are the crown's captain, go? attend,
Let our bay courser wait.

div.stage: Enter phoenix and Fidelio both disguised.

sp.speaker: Lackey.
sp.l: It shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: A farmer's son, is't true?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Has crowns to scatter?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I give you your salute sir.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I take it not unthankfully sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I hear a good report of you sir — you've money.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I have so, true.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: An excellent virtue.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ay, to keep from you — hear you me captain?
sp.p: I have a certain generous itch sir, to lose a few angels in the way of profit: 'tis but a game at tennis,
sp.l: Where if the ship keep above line, 'tis three to one:
If not, there's but three hundred angels gone.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Is your venture three hundred? you're very preciously welcome: here's a voyage toward will make us all. —

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Beggarly fools, and swarming knaves.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Captain, what's he?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fear him not my lord, he's a gull , he ventures with me, some filthy farmer's son, the father's a Jew, and the son a gentleman: pha. —

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Yet he should be a Jew too, for he is new come from giving over swine.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, that in our country makes him a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Go to, tell your money captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Read aloft scrivener. 1.2. —

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To all good and honest Christian people, to whom this present writing shall come: know you for a certain, that I captain, for and in the consideration of the sum of five hundred crowns, have clearly bargained, sold, given, granted, assigned and set over, and by these presents do clearly bargain, sell, give, grant, assign and set over, all the right, estate, title, interest, demand, possession, and term of years to come, which I the said captain have, or ought to have. —

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: If I were as good as I should be, —

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
In and to madonna Castiza, my most virtuous,
modest, loving, and obedient wife. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: By my troth my lord and so she is. — 3.4.5.6.7.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The more slave he that says it, and not sees it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Together, with all and singular those admirable qualities with which her noble breast is furnished.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well said scrivener, hast put 'em all in: you shall hear now my l.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: In primis, the beauties of her mind, chastity, temperance, and above all, patience:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You have bought a jewel i'faith, my l, nine and thirty, forty.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Excellent in the best of music, in voice delicious: in conference wise and pleasing: of age contentful: neither too young to be a pish, nor too old to be sottish

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You have bought as lovely a pennyworth my lord, as ere you bought in your life.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Why should I buy her else captain?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And which is the best, of a wife a most comfortable sweet companion.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I could not afford her so i'faith, but that I am-going to sea and have need of money.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A most comfortable sweet companion.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: What again? the scrivener reads in passion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I read as the words move me: yet if that be a fault it shall be seen no more, — which said madonna Castiza lying, and yet being in the occupation of the said captain

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nineteen — occupation? Pox out, out with occupation, a captain is of no occupation, man.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Nor thou of no religion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now I come to the habendum, to have and to hold, use and —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Use? put out use too for shame.
Till we are all gone, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And to be acquitted of and from all former bargains, former sales:

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Former sails, nine and twenty thirty, by my troth
my lord, this is the first time that ever I sold her.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Yet the writing must run so captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Let it run on then, nine and forty, fifty, —

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Former sales, gifts, grants, surrenders. Reentryes. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: For re-entries, I will not swear for her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And furthermore (I then said) of and for the consideration of the sum of five hundred crowns to set me a board before these presents utterly disclaim for ever, any title, estate, right, interest, demand, or possession, in or to the said madonna Castiza, my late virtuous, and unfortunate wife.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Unfortunate indeed, that was well placed.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As also neither to touch, attempt, molest, or encumber any part, or parts whatsoever: either to be named or not to be named: either hidden or unhidden, either those that boldly look abroad, or those that dare not show their face.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faces: I know what you mean by faces: scrivener, there's a great figure in faces.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: In witness whereof, I the said captain have interchangeably set to my hand and seal: in presence of all these, the day and date above written.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Very good sir, I'll be ready for you presently, four hundred and twenty. 1.2.3.4.5. —

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Of all deeds, yet this strikes the deepest wound
Into my apprehension,
Reverend, and honourable matrimony,
Mother of lawful sweets, unshamed mornings:
Dangerless pleasures, thou that mak'st the bed,
Both pleasant, and legitimately fruitful: without thee,
All the whole world were soiled bastardy.
Thou art the only and the greatest form.
That puttest a difference between our desires
And the disordered appetites of beasts,
Making their mates, those that stand next their lusts.
Then, — with what base injury is thy goodness paid
First, rare to have a bride commence a maid,
But does beguile joy of the purity:
And is made strict by power of drugs and art,
An artificial maid, a doctor virgin,
And so deceives the glory of his bod:
A foul contempt, against the spotless power
Of sacred wedlock, but if chaste and honest,
There is another devil haunts marriage,
(None fondly loves but knows it) jealousy,
That wedlock's yellow sickness, that whispering separation every minute.
And thus the curse takes his effect or progress,
The most of men in their first sudden furies,
Rail at the narrow bounds of marriage,
And cal't a prison than it is most just,
That the disease a'th' prison, jealousy
Should still affect 'em, but o! here I am fixed,
To make sale of a wife, monstrous and foul,
An act abhorred in nature, could in soul:
Who that has man in him, could so resign,
To make his shame, the poesy to the coin?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Right i'faith, my lord fully five hundred,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: I said how you should find it captain, and with this competent sum you rest amply contented.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Amply contented.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Here's the pen captain: your name to the sale.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Sfoot dost take me to be a penman? I protest I could ne'er write more than a, b, c, those three letters in my life.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Why those will serve captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I could ne'er get further.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Would you have got further than a b c? ah base captain, that's far enough i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Take the seal off captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It goes on hardly, and comes off easily.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I just like a coward.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Will you write witness gentleman?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: He? he shall, prithee come and set thy hand for witness rogue, thou shall venture with me?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, than I ha' reason captain that commands me?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What a fair fist the pretty whoreson writes, as if he had had manners and bringing up, a farmer's son: his father damns himself to sell musty corn, while he ventures the money, 'twill prosper well at sea no doubt he shall ne'er see't again

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: So, captain you deliver this as your deed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: As my deed, what else sir?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The ugliest deed that ere mine eye did witness

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So my lord, you have her, clip her, enjoy her, she's your own, and let me be proud to tell you now my lord, she's as good a soul if a man had a mind to live honest, and keep a wench, the kindest, sweetest, comfortablest rogue. —

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Hark in thine ear,
The baser slave art thou: and so I'll tell her,
I love the pearl, thou sold'st, hate thee the seller —
Go, to sea, the end of thee — is lousy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This fine work: a very brave end, hum —

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Well thought upon, this scrivener may furnish me

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why should this fellow be a lord by birth?
Being by blood a knave, one that would sell
His lordship if he liked her ladyship.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: What's here now?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I have employment for a trusty fellow, bold, sure —

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What if he be a knave my lord?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p:
There thou com'st to me, why he should be so,
and men of your quill are not unacquainted.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed all our chief living my lord, is by fools and knaves, we could not keep open shop else ▪ fools that enter into bonds, and knaves that bind 'em.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Why now we meet.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And as my memory happily leads me: I know a fellow of a standing estate, never flowing: I durst convey treason into his bosom,
sp.l: And keep it safe nine years.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: A goodly time.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: And if need were would press to an attempt,
And cleave to desperate action.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: That last fits me.
Thou hast the measure right, look I hear from thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: With duteous speed.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Expect a large reward:
I will find time of her to find regard.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The end of me is lousy.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O my lord! I have strange words to tell you.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Stranger yet? I'll choose some other hour to listen to thee, I am yet sick of this, discover quickly.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why, will you make yourself known my lord

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I.
Who scourgeth sin let him do't dreadfully.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Pox of his dissemblance: I will to s●n.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, you shall to sea, thou wouldst poison the whole land else — why how now captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: In health.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What, drooping?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Or a shamed of the sale of thine own wife?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: You might count me an ass then i'faith.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: If not a shamed of that, what can you be a shamed of then?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Prithee ha' done, I am ashamed of nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I easily believe that.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: This lord sticks in my stomach.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How? take one of thy feathers down, and fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I'd make him come.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what if the Duke should hear of this?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Ay, or your son in law, Fidelio knows of the sale of his mother.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What and they did, I sell none but mine own: as for the Duke, he's abroad by this time, and for Fidelio he's in labour.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: He, in labour?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What call you travelling?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: That's true: — but let me tell you captain: whether the Duke hear on't, or Fidelio know on't: or both, or neither, 'twas a most filthy loathsome part.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: A base unnatural deed —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Slave and fool: — ha, who? o —

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou hateful villain: thou shouldst choose (To sink
To keep thy baseness shrouded.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ugly wretch.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: Who hath laid violence upon my husband?
My dear sweet captain, help —

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady you wrong your value,
Call you him dear that has sold you so cheap?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I do beseech your pardon good my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Rise.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My abused mother:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My kind son,
Whose liking I neglected in this match.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Not that alone, but you far happier fortunes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Is this the scrivener and the farmer's son,
Fire on his lordship he told me they travailed.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And see the sum told out to buy that jewel
More precious in a woman than her eye, her honour:
Nay take it to you lady, and judge it,
sp.p:
Too slight a recompense, for your great wrong, but that
his riddance helps it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Sfoot he undoes me, I am a rogue and a beggar,
The Egyptian plague creeps over me already,
I begin to be lousy.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Thus happily prevented, you're set free,
Or else made over to adultery.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: To heaven and to you my modest thanks.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Monster, to sea, spit thy all herred foam,
Where it may do least harm, there's air and roeme.
Thour't dangerous in a chamber, Virulext venem,
Unto a lady's name, and her chaste breath
If passed this evenings's verge, the dukedom hold thee,
Thou art reserved for abject punishment.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I do beseech your good lordship consider the state of a poor downcast captain.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Captain, off with that noble title thou becomest it vildly, I ne'er saw the name fit worse, I'll sooner allow a pandar a captain than thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: More's the pity.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sue to thy lady for pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I give it without suit.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I do beseech your ladyship not so much for pardon, as to bestow a few of those crowns upon a poor unfeather rover that will as truly pray for you, and wish you hanged, as any man breathing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I give it freely all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay by your favour:
I will contain you lady, here ▪ be gone:
Use slaves like slaves — wealth keeps their faults unknown.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Well I'm yet glad, I've liberty and these:
The land has plagued me, and I'll plague the seas.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The scene is cleared, the bane of brightness fled
Who sought the death of honour, is struck dead.
Come modest lady:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: My most honest mother.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thy virtue shall live safe from reach of shames,
That act ends nobly, preserves ladies' fames.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why this is but the second time of your coming kinsman, visit me oftener, daughter, I charge you bring this gentleman along with you: gentleman, I I cry ye mercy sir, I call you gentleman still: I forget you're but a knight, you must pardon me sir.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: For your worship's kindness — worship I cry you mercy sir, I call you worshipful still, I forget, you're but a justice.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I am no more i'faith.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: You must pardon me sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: 'Tis quickly done sir, you see I make bold with you kinsman, thrust my daughter and you into one chamber.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Best of all sir: kindred you know may lie anywhere .

sp.speaker: Fals
sp.p: True, true sir, daughter receive your blessing — take heed the coach jopper not to much ▪ have a care to the fruits of your body — look to her kinsman.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Fear it not sir.

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: Nay father though I say it, that should not say it, he looks to me more like a husband then a kinsman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I hear good commendations of you sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: You hear the worst of me I hope sir, — I salute my leave sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: You're welcome all over your body sir: nay, I can behave myself courtly, though I keep house ith' country: what, does my niece hide herself, not present, ha? Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Call my niece to me.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
A foolish, coy, bashful thing it is, she's afraid
to lie with her own uncle: I'd do her no harm i'faith, I keep myself a widower a purpose, yet the foolish girl will not look into't, she should have all i'faith, she knows I have but a time, cannot hold long, see where she comes, pray whom am I niece?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I hope you're yourself.
Uncle to me, and brother to my father.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: O am I so, it does not appear so, — for surely you would love your father's brother for your father's sake, your uncle for your own sake.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I do so.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay you do nothing niece.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: In that love which becomes you best I love (You.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How should I know that love becomes me best?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Because 'tis chaste, and honourable.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Honourable! it cannot become me then niece.
For I'm scarce worshipful: is this an age,
To entertain bare love without the fruits
When I received thee first, I looked
Thou shouldst have been a wife unto my house
And saved me from the charge of marriage.
sp.p: Do you think your fathers five thousand pound would ha' made me take you else? no, you should ne'er a ha' been a charge to me.
sp.l: As far as I can perceive yet by you,
sp.p: I've as much need to marry as ere I had: would not this be a great grief to your friends think you, if they were alive again?

sp.speaker: Niece:
sp.l: 'Twould be a grief indeed.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You've confessed
All about house, that young Fidelio
Who in his travails does attend the prince,
Is your vowed love.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Most true, he's my vowed husband.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
And what's a husband is not a husband a stranger at first, and will you lie with a stranger before
you lie with your own uncle? take heed what ye do niece, I counsel you for the best: strangers are drunken fellows I can tell you, they will come home late a nights, beat their wives, and get nothing but girls: look to't, if you marry, your stubborness is your dowry: five thousand crowns were bequeathed to you, true, if you marry with my consent: but if ere you go to marrying by my consent, I'll go to hanging by yours: go too ▪ be wise and love your uncle.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I should have cause then to repent indeed.
Do you so far forget the offices
Of blushing modesty? Uncles are half fathers,
Why they come so near our bloods they're e'en part of it.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why now you come to me niece: if your uncle be part of your own flesh and blood, is it not then fit your own flesh and blood should come nearest to you? answer me to that niece.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You do allude all to incestuous will,
Nothing to modest purpose: turn me forth,
Be like an uncle of these latter days,
Perjured enough, enough unnatural,
Play your executorship, in tyranny,
Restrain my fortunes, keep me poor, I care not,
In this alone most women I'll excel,
I'll rather yield to beggary then to hell.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Very good, a my troth my niece is valiant, sha's made me richer by five thousand crowns, the price of her dowry: are you so honest, I do not fear but I shall have the conscience to keep you poor enough niece, or else I am quite altered a late — the news, may it please you sir?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: Sir, there's an old fellow, a kind of law-driver, entreats conference with your worship.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: A law-driver, prithee drive him hither.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: No, no I say if it be for defect of appearance, take me out a special significavit.

sp.speaker: Whin.
sp.l: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Then if he purchase an alias or capias, which are writs of custom, only to delay time, your procedendo does you knights service — that's nothing at all, get your distringas out as soon as you can for a jury.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: I'll attend your god worships coming out.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Do I prithee, attend me, I'll take it kindly, a voluntate.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What, old Seigneur tangle!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I am in debt to your worship's remembrance.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My old master of fence: come, come, come, I have not exercised this twelve moons, I have almost forgotten all my law-weapons.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: They are under fine and recovery, your worship shall easily recover them.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I hope so: when there?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: The rapler and dagger foils instantly: and what's thy suit to me old tangle, I'll grant it presently.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nothing but this sir, to set your worship's hand to the commendation of a knave whom nobody speaks well on.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: The more shame for 'em, what was his offence I pray?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Vestras deducite culpas — nothing but robbing a vestry.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
What, what! alas poor knave, give me the paper, he did but save the churchwardens a labour: come, come, he has done a better deed in't then the parish is a aware off, to prevent the knaves, he robs but seldom, they once a quarter: methinks 'twere a part of good justice, to hang 'em at years end, when they come out of
their office, to the true terrifying of all collectors and sidemen.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your worship would make a fruitful commonwealth's man, the constable lets 'em alone, looks on, and says nothing.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: A lass good man, he lets 'em alone for quietness' sake, and takes half a share with 'em: they know well enough too, he has an impediment in his tongue, he's always drunk when he should speak.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Indeed your worship speaks true in that sir: they blind him with beer, and make him so narrow eyed, that he winks naturally at all their knaveries,

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: So, so, here's my hand to his commendations.

sp.speaker: Tangle.
sp.l: A charitate, you do a charitable deed in't sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, if it be but a vestry matter, visit me at any time, old signior law-thistle! O well done, here are the foils, come, come sir, I'll try a law-bout with you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: I am afraid I shall overthrow you sir i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: 'Tis but for want of use then sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Indeed that same odd word use, makes a man a good lawyer, and a woman an arrant — tuh tuh, tuh, tuh, tuh, now am I for you sir: but first to bring you into form, can your worship name all your weapons?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: That I can I hope, let me see, longsword, what's longsword? I am so dulled with doing justice, that I have forgotten all i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Your long sword, that's a writ of delay.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Mass that swords long enough indeed, I ha' known it reach the length of fifteen terms.

sp.speaker: Tang
sp.l: Fifteen terms, that's but a short sword.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Methinks 'tis long enough, proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A writ of delay, longsword.
Scandala magnatum, backsword.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Scandals are back-swords indeed

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Capias cominus, case of rapiers.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: O desperate!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A latitat, sword and dagger.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: A writ of execution, rapier and dagger.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Thou art come to our present weapon, but what call you sword and buckler then?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh! that's out of use now, sword and buckler was called a good conscience, but that weapons left long ago, that was too manly a fight, too sound a weapon for these our days, 'slid we are scarce able to lift up a buckler now, our arms are so bound to the pox: one good bang upon a buckler would make most of our gentlemen fly a pieces, 'tis not for these linty times, our lawyers are good rapier and dagger men, they'll quickly dispatch your — money.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Indeed since sword and buckler time, I have observed, there has been nothing so much fighting: where be all our gallant swaggerers? there are no good frays o'late.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: O sir, the properties altered, you shall see less fighting every day then other, for every one gets him a mistress, and she gives him wounds enough, and you know, the surgeons cannot be here and there too, if there were red wounds too, what would become of the reinish wounds?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Thou sayest true i'faith, they would be but ill favouredly looked to then.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I expect you sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I lie in this court for you sir, my rapier is my attorney, and my dagger his clerk.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Your attorney wants a little oiling, methinks , he looks very rustily.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis but his proper colour sir, his father was an iremonger, he will ne'er look brighter, the rust has so eat into him, has never any leisure to be made clean.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Not in the vacation.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Non vacat exiguis rebus adesse jovi.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Then Jove will not be at leisure to scour him, because he ne'er came to him before.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: You're excellent at it sir — and now you lest think on't, I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay very bad sir by my faith — I follow you still, as the officers will follow you as long as you have a penny.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: You speak sentences sir — by this time have I tried my friends, and now I thrust in bail —

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: This bail will not be taken sir, they must be two citizens that are no cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: By’r lady then I'm like to lie by it, I had rather 'twere a hundred that were.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Take heed I bring you not to an nisiprius sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I must ward myself as well as I may sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Tis court day now, declarat atturnatus, my attorney gapes for money.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You shall have no advantage yet, I put in my answer.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I follow the suit still sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I like not this court by’r lady — I: take me out a writ of remove, a writ of remove, do you see sir?

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: And place my cause higher.

sp.speaker: Tang,
sp.p: There you started me sir — yet for all your demurs, plures, and sursurarers, which are all longswords: that's delays: all the comfort is, in nine years a man may overthrow you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You must thank your good friends then sir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Let nine years pass, five hundred crowns cast away a both sides, and the suit not twenty, my counsellors wife must have another hood you know, and my attorneys wife will have a new forepart, yet
see at length law, I shall have law: now beware, I bring you to a narrow exigent, and by no means can you avoid the proclamation —

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now follows a writ of execution, a capias, ut legatum, gives you a wound mortal, trips up your heels, and lays you ith' counter.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: O villain!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I cry your worship heartily mercy sir, I thought we had been in law together, aduersarius contra aduersarium by my troth.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Oh! reach me thy hand, I ne'er had such an overthrow in my life.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: 'Twas long of your attorney there, he might a stayed the execution of capias ut legatum, and removed you with a supersedeas non molestandum into the court of equity.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Pox on him, he fell out of my hand when I had most need of him,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I was bound to follow the suit sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou couldst do no less than overthrow me,
I must needs say so.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: You had recovered cost else sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: And now by'th mass I think I shall hardly recover without cost.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Certoscio, an execution is very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Well, it shall teach me wit as long as I am a justice: I perceive by this trial, if a man have a sound fall in law, he shall feel it in his bones all his life after.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Recto upon record, for I myself was overthrown in eighty eight by a tailor, and I have had a stitch in my side ever since, o!

div.stage: Towards the close of the music, the justices three men prepare for a robbery.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Why Latronello, furtivo, Fucato, where be these lazy knaves that should truss me, not one stirring yet?

sp.speaker: A cry within.
sp.p: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What news there?

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: This way, this way, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Hark you sluggish soporiferous villains, there's knaves abroad when you are a-bed , are ye not a shamed on't, a justice's men should be up first, and give example all knaves.

div.stage: Enter two of his men tumbling in, in false beards.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: O I beseech your good worship.

sp.speaker: Fuca.
sp.l: Your worshipful worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thieves, my two hand sword, I'm robbed ith' hall, Latronello, knaves, come down, my two hand sword I

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: I am Latronello, I beseech your worship, (Say.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou Latronello, thou liest, my men scorn to have beards.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: We forget our beards, now I beseech your worship quickly remember us.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.l: Nay there's no time to talk of how now, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: Four mark and a livery is not able to keep life and soul together, we must fly out once a quart, 'tis for your worship's credit to have money in our purse, our fellow furtivo is taken in the action.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A pox on him for a lazy knave, would he be taken?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.p: They bring him along to your worship, your the next justice, now or never show yourself a good master, an upright magistrate, and deliver him out of their hands.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, he shall find me — apt enough to do him good I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Latr:
sp.l: He comes in a false beard sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: 'Sfoot what, should he do here else? there's no coming to me in a true on: if he had one, — the slave to be taken: do not I keep geldings swift enough?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: The goodliest geldings of any gentleman in the shire.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Which did the whoreson knave ride upon?

sp.speaker: Enter.
sp.l: Upon one of your best sir.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: Stand and deliver.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Upon stand and deliver: the very gelding I choose for mine own riding, as nimble as Pegasus the flying horse yonder: go shift yourselves into your coats, bring hither a great chair, and a little table.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: With all present speed sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: And Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Ay sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Sit you down, and very soberly take the examination.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: I'll draw a few horse heads in a paper, make a show: I hope I shall keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Fals.
