sp.p: Pox on him again, would he be taken? he frets me: I have been a youth myself, I ha' seen the day I could have told money out of other men's purses (Mass so I can do now) nor will I keep that fellow about me that dares not bid a man stand: for as long as drunkenness is a vice, stand is a virtue: but I would not have 'em taken. I remember now betimes in a morning I would have peeped through the green boughs, and have had the party presently, and then to ride away sinelye in fear, 'twas e'en venery to me i'faith, the pleasantst course of life, one would think every woodcok a constable, and every owl an officer, but those days are passed with me: and a my troth I think I am a greater thief now, and in no danger: I can take my ease, sit in my chair, look in your faces now, and rob you, make you bring your money by authority put off your hat, and thank me for robbing of you, oh there is nothing to a thief under covert barn.

div.stage: Enter phoenix, Fidelio being robbed, constable, officers and the thief Furtino.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Come officers bring him away.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Nay, I see thee through thy false beard, thou mid-wind chinned rascal,
sp.l: How now my masters, what's he? ha?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Your worship knows, I never come but I bring a thief with me.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Thou hast left thy wont else constable.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Sir, we understand you to be the only up rightness of this place.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: But I scare understand you sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why then you understand not yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Such another word, and you shall change places with the thief.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A maintainer of equal causes I mean.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Now I have you, proceed sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This gentleman and myself, being led hither by occasion of business, have been offered the discourtesy of the country, set upon by three thieves and robbed.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: What are become of the other two, Latronello, and Fuca?

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: They both made away from us, the cry pursues 'em, but as yet none but this taken.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Take his examination.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Let the knave stand single.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Thank your good worship.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Has been a suitor at court sure, he thanks me for nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: He's a thief now sure.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: That we must know of him, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: A piece next to the tail sir — a servingman.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
By my troth a pretty phrase and very
cleanly handled, put it down Latronello: thou mayst make use on't. Is he of honour or worship whom thou servest?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Of both dear sir, honourable in mind, and worshipful in body.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Why would one wish a man to speak better?

sp.speaker: Phoen
sp.l: O sir, they most commonly speak best, that do worst.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Say you so sir, then we'll try him farther, — does your right worshipful master, go before you, as an ensample of vice, and so encourage you to this slinking iniquity? he is not a lawer, is he?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Has the more wrong sir, both for his conscience, and honesty, he deserves to be one.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pity he's thief i'faith, I should entertain him else.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Ay, if he were not as he is, he would be better than himself.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: No 'tis well known sir, I have a master, the very picture of wisdom,

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: For indeed he speaks not one wise word.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And no man but will admire to hear of his virtues.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Because he ne'er had any in all his life.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You write all down Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: So sober, so discrete, so judicious:

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And above all, of most reverend gravity.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I like him for one quality, he speaks well of his master, he will fare the better: — now sir, let me touch you,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Ay sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p:
Why, serving a gentleman of such worship and wisdom, such sobriety and virtue, such discretion and judgement as your master is, do you take such a beastly
course, to stop horses, hinder gentlewomen from their meetings, and make citizens never ride but a Sundaies, only to avoid morning prayer and you: is it because your worshipful ma. feeds you with lean spits, pays you with Irish money, or clothes you in Northern dozens?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Far be it from his mind, or my report, 'tis well known he kept worshipful cheer the day of his wife's burial, pays our four marks a year as duly by twelve pence a quarter as can be.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: His wisdom swallows it.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And for Northern dozens, fie, fie, we were ne'er troubled with so many.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Receiving then such plenteous blessings from your virtuous and bountiful master, what cause have you to be thief now? answer me to that gear:

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: 'Tis e'en as a man gives his mind to't sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: For alas, if the whole world were but of one trade; traffic were nothing: if we were all truemen, we should be of no trade: what a pitiful world would here be, heaven forbid we should be all truemen: then how should your worships next suit be made? not a tailor left in the land: of what stuff would you have it made? not a merchant left to deliver it, would your worship go in that suit still? You would ha' more thieves about you then those you have banished, and be glad to call the great ones home again, to destroy the little.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A notable rogue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A my troth, a fine knave, and has answered me gloriously, what wages wilt thou take after thou art hanged?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: More than your worship's able to give, I would think foul scorn to be a justice then.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: He says true too i'fath, for we are all full of corruption here, — hark you my friends.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: By my troth if you were no crueler than I, I could find in my heart to let him go.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Could you so sir, the more pitiful justice you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay I did but to try you, if you have no pity, I'll ha' none, away he's a thief, to prison with him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: I am content sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Are you content, bring him back, nay then you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I'll be as cruel as you can wish: you're content, belike you have a trick to break prison, or a bribe for the officers.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: For us sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: For you sir? what colour's silver I pray, you ne'er saw money in your life: — I'll not trust you with him, Latronello and Fucato, lay hold upon him, to your charge I commit him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: O, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Nay if I must be cruel, I will be cruel.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Good sir, let me rather go to prison.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You desire that ▪ — I'll trust no prison with you, I'll make you lie in mine own house, or I'll know why I shall not.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Merciful sir.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Since you have no pity I will be cruel.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Very good sir, you please us well.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: You shall appear tomorrow sirs.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Upon my knees sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You shall be hanged out a'th way, away with him Latronello, and Fucato, — officers I discharge you my house, I like not your company.
sp.l: Report me as you see me, fire and fuel,
If men be Jews, justices must be cruel.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: So sir, extremes set of all actions thus,
Either too tame, or else too tyrannous:
He being bent to fury, I doubt now
we shall not gain access unto your love or she to us.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Most wishfully here she comes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Is that she?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: This is she my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A modest presence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Virtue bless you lady,

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You wish me well sir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I'd first in charge this kiss, and next this paper,
You'll know the language, 'tis Fidelios.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: My ever vowed love, how is his health?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: As fair as is his favour with the prince.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I'm sick with joy, does the prince love him so?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: His life cannot requite it,
Not to wrong the remembrance of his love,
I had a token for you, kept it safe,
Till by misfortune of the way this morning,
Thieves set upon this gentleman and myself,
And with the rest robbed that.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: O me, I'm dear sorry for your chance, was it your loss?
They boldly look you in the face that robbed you,
No farther villains than my uncle's men.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: 'Tis my grief I speak so true.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why my lord?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But give me pausing lady: was he one that took the examination?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: One and the chief.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Henceforth hang him that is no way a thief,
sp.p: Then I hope few will suffer, — nay all the jest was, he committed him to the charge of his fellows, and the rogue made it lamentable, cried to leave 'em.
sp.l: None live so wise but fools may once deceive 'em?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: An uncle so insatiate?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Ay, is't not strange too,
That all should be by nature vicious, and he bade against
Nature?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Then you have heard the sum of all my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady, we have, and desire rather now
To heal 'em, than to hear 'em:
For by a letter from Fidelio
Direct to us, we are entreated jointly,
To hasten your remove ▪ from this foul den,
Of theft and purposed incest:

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I rejoice in his chaste care of me, I'll soon be furnished.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He writes that his return cannot be long.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I'm chiefly glad, — but whither is the place?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: To the safe seat of his late wronged mother.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I desire it, —
Her conference will fit mine, well you prevail,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: At next grove we'll expect you:

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I'll not fail.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: It stands upon the frame of my reputation I protest lady.

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: Lady, that word is worth an hundred angels at all times, for it cost more: if I live till tomorrow night, my sweet pleasure thou shalt have them.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Could you not make 'em a hundred and fifty think you?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I'll do my best endeavour to multiply, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Could you not make 'em two hundred?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No by my faith. —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Peace, I'll rather be confined in the hundred and fifty.

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: Come e'en much about this time, when taverns give up their ghosts, and gentlemen are in their first cast. —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: I'll observe the season.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
And do but whirl the ring a'th door once about,
my maidservant shall be taught to understand the language.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Enough my sweet revenue.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Good rest my effectual pleasure.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Come hither phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What makes your honour break so early?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: A toy, I have a toy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A toy my lord.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Before thou layest thy wrath upon the Duke, — be advised.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Ay, ay, I warrant you my lord.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Nay, give my words honour, hear me,
I'll strive to bring this act into such form,
And credit amongst men, they shall suppose.
Nay verily believe the prince his son,
To be the plotter of his father's murder.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: O that were infinitely admirable!

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Wert not, it pleaseth me beyond my bliss:

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Then if his son meet death as he returns,
Or by my hired instruments turn up,
The general voice will cry — oh happy vengeance!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O blessed vengeance!

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Ay, I'll turn my brain
Into a thousand uses, tire my inventions,
Make my blood sick with study, and mine eye
More hollow than my heart, but I will fashion,
Nay I will fashion it, — canst counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The prince's hand, more truly, most direct,
You shall admire it.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Necessary mischief.
Next to a woman, but more close in secrets
Thou'rt all the kindred that my breast vouchsafes ,
Look into me anon, — I must frame, and muse, and
Fashion —

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: 'Twas time to look into thee, in whose heart
Treason grows ripe, and therefore fit to fall,
That slave first sinks, whose envy threatens all,
Now is his venom at full height.

sp.speaker: 1 voice
sp.p: Lying, or being in the said county in the tenor and occupation aforesaid.

sp.speaker: 2 voice.
sp.p: No more then, a writ of course upon the matter of —

sp.speaker: 3. Voice.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: 4. Voice.
sp.p: O o-o-o-yes Carlo Turbulenzo, appear or lose twenty mark in the suits.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Ha? whither have my thoughts conveyed me? I am now within the dizzy murmur of the law.

sp.speaker: 1 voice.
sp.p: So that then, the cause being found clear, upon the last citation.

sp.speaker: 4 voice.
sp.l: Carlo turbulenzo, come into the court.

div.stage: Enter Tangle with two after him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now, now, now, now, now, upon my knees I praise Mercury the god of law, I have two suits at issue, two suits at issue.

sp.l: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I will not hear, I've other business.
I beseech you my learned counsel.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Beseech not me, beseech not me, I am a mortal man, a client as you are, beseech not me.
I would do all by your worship's direction.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Then hang thyself.
Shall I take out a special supplicavit.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Mad me not, torment me not, tear me not, you'll give me leave to hear mine own cause, mine own cause

sp.speaker: 1. Voice.
sp.p: Nay moreover, and farther —

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Well said my lawyer, well said, well said.

sp.speaker: 1. Voice.
sp.p: All the opprobious speeches that man could invent all malicious invectives, called wittol to his face.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: That's I, that's I, thank you my learned counsel for your good remembrance: I hope I shall overthrow him horse and foot.

sp.l: Nay but good sir.

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: No more sir, he that brings me happy news first I'll relieve first.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Sound executions rot thy cause and thee.

sp.speaker: Ta:
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, pray so still, pray so still, they'll thrive the better

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I wonder how this fellow keeps out madness?
What stuff his brains are made on?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I suffer, I suffer, — till I hear a judgement.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What old signior?

sp.speaker: Tan
sp.p: Prithee I will not know thee now, 'tis a busy time, a busy time with me.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What not me signior?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: O cry thee mercy, give me thy hand, — fare thee well, — has no relief again me then, — his demurs will not help him, his Sursarara's will but play the knaves with him.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: The justice: 'tis he

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Have I found thee i'faith? I thought where I should smell thee out old tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: What old signior justicer, — embrace me another time and you can possible: how does all thy wife's children, — well? that's well said i'fath.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Hear me old tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Prithee do not ravish me, let me go.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I must use some of thy counsel first.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ha' brought him to an exigent ▪ hark that's my cause, that's my cause yonder, I twinge him, I twinge him.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My niece is stolen away.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah, get me a ne exeat regno quickly, nay you must not stay upon't, I'd fain have you gone.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: A ne exeat regno, I'll about it presently, — adieu.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: You seek to catch her justice, she'll catch you.
A judgement, a judgement.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: What, what, what?
Overthrown, overthrown, overthrown.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Ha, a, a.
News, news, news.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: The devil, the devil, the devil.
Twice tangle's overthrown, twice tangles overthrown.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Hold:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now old cheater of the law,

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to be mad.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
Thou that hast found such sweet pleasure in
the vexation of others.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: May I not be mad in quiet?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Very marrow, very manna to thee to be in law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Very syrup of toads, and preserved adders.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou that hast vexed, and beggared the whole
Parish, and made the honest church wardens go to
Law with the poors money.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Hear me, do but hear me, I pronounce a terrible, horrible curse upon you all — and wish you to my attorney: see where a praemunire comes a dedimus potestatem, and that most dreadful execution, excommunicato capiendo, there's no bail to be taken, I shall rot in fifteen jails: make dice of my bones, and let my counsellors son play away his father's money with 'em; may my bones revenge my quarrel! — a capias cominus? here, here, here, here: quickly dip your quills in my blood, off with my skin and write fourteen lines of a side — there's an honest conscionable fellow, he takes but ten shillings of a bellows-mender — here's another deals all with charity, you shall give him nothing, only his wife an embroidered petticoat, a gold fringe for her tail, or a border for her head, ah sirrah! you shall catch me no more in the springe of your knaveries.
Follow, follow him still, a little thing now sets him forward.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: None can except against him, the man's mad,
And privileged by the moon, if he say true:
Less madness 'tis to speak sin, than to do.
This wretch that loved before, his food, his strife,
This punishment falls even with his life.
His pleasure was vexation, all his bliss
The torment of another.
Their heart, his health: their starved hopes his store,
Who so loves law, dies either mad or poor.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A miracle, a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How now Fidelio?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My lord a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I have found
One quiet, suffering, and unlawyered man.
An opposite, a very contrary
To the old turbulent fellow.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why he's mad.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Mad, why he is in his right wits, could he be madder than he was, if he be any way altered from what he was, 'tis for the better, my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well, but where's this wonder?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: 'Tis coming my lord: a man so truly a man, so indifferently a creature, using the world in his right nature but to tread upon, one that would not bruise, the cowardly est enemy to man, the worm, that dares not show his malice till we are dead: nay my lord, you will admire his temper! see where he comes, I promised your acquaintance, sir
sp.l: Yond is the gentleman I did commend for temper.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Let me embrace you simply.
That's perfectly, and more in heart than hand:
Let affectation keep at court.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ay, let it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'Tis told me you love quiet

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Above wealth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I above life: I have been wild and rash
Committed many and unnatural crimes,
Which I have since repented.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: 'Twas well spent.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I was mad, stark mad, nine years together.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I pray! as how?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Going to law, i'faith it made me mad.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: With the like frenzy not an hour since
An aged man was struck.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Alas I pity him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: He's not worth pitying, for 'twas still his gladness to be at variance.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Yet a man's worth pity,
My quiet blood has blessed me with this gift,
I have cured some, and if his wits be not
Too deeply cut, I will assay to help 'em.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sufferance does teach you pity.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O master, master, your abominable next neighbour came into the house, being half in drink, and took away your best carpet.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Has he it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alas sir:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Let him go, trouble him not, lock the door quietly after him, and have a safer care who comes in next.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: But sir, might I advise you, in such a cause as this, a man might boldly, nay ▪ with conscience go to law.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: O, I'll give him the table too first. Better endure a fist then a sharp sword: I had rather they should pull off my clothes then flay of my skin, and hang that on mine enemy's hedge.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why, for such good causes was the law ordained:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: True, and in itself 'tis glorious and divine,
Law is the very master piece of heaven:
But see yonder.
There's many clouds between the sun and us,
There's too much cloth before we see the law:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'm content with that answer, be mild still,
'Tis honour to forgive those you could kill.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: There do I keep.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Reach me your hand, I love you,
And you shall know me better.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: 'Tis my suit.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The night grows deep — and —

sp.speaker: 1 off:
sp.l: Come away, this way, this way.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Who be those? stand close a little.

div.stage: Jars the ring of the door, the maid enters catches him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O, you're come as well as ere you came in your life, my master's new gone to bed, give me your knightly hand, I must lead you into the blind parlour, my mistress will be down to you presently.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: I tell you our safest course will be to arrest him when he comes out a'th tavern: for then he will be half drunk, and will not stand upon his weapon.

sp.l: Our safest course indeed, for he will draw.

sp.p: That he will, though he put it up again, which is more of his courtesy, then of our deserving.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: The world is nothing but vexation,
Spite and uncharitable action.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Did you see the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Where should he be, it may be he's passed by,
Good sir, let's overtake him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here sir, now you are there sir, she'll come down to you instantly, I must not stay with you, my mistress would be jealous, you must do nothing to me, my mistress would find it quickly.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: 'Sfoot whither am I led? brought in byth' hand? I hope it can be no harm to stay for a woman, though indeed they were never more dangerous, I have ventured hitherto and safe, and I must venture to stay now, this should be a fair Rome, but I see it not, the blind parlour calls she it?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Where art thou, oh my knight!

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Your knight, I am the Duke's knight.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I say you're my knight, for I'm sure I paid for you

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Paid for you hum, — 'sfoot a light. —

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Now out upon the marmoset, hast thou served me so long, and offer to bring in a candle?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Fair room, villainous face, and worse woman, I ha' learned something by a glimpse ath' candle:

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: How happened it you came so soon, I looked not for you these two hours: yet as the sweet chance is, you came as well as a thing could come, for my husband's newly brought a-bed .

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And what has Jove sent him?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: He ne'er sent him any thing since I knew him, he's a man of a bad nature to his wife, none but his maids can thrive under him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Ay, judge whether I have a cause to be a courtesan or no? to do as I do, an elderly fellow as he is, if he were married to a young virgin, he were able to break her heart, though he could break nothing else: here, here, there's just a hundred and fifty, but I stole 'em so hardly from him, 'twould e'en have grieved you to have seen it.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: So 'twould i'faith.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Therefore prithee my sweet pleasure, do not keep company so much, how do you think I am able to maintain you? though I be a jeweller's wife, jewels are like women, they rise and fall, we must be content to lose sometimes, to gain often, but you're content always to lose, and never to gain: what need you ride with a footman before you?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: O that's the grace,

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.p: The grace? 'tis sufficient grace that you've a horse to ride upon, you should think thus with yourself every time you go to bed if my head were laid, what would become of that horse? he would run a bad race then as well as his master.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay, and you give me money to chide me: —

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.p: No, if it were as much more, I would think it foul scorn to chide you, I advise you to be thrifty, to take the time now, while you have it, you shall seldom get such another fool as I am, I warrant you: why there's mettrezza Auriola keeps her love with half the cost that I am at, her friend can go a foot like a good husband, walk in worsted stockings, and inquire for the sixpenny ordinary.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Pox on't, and would you have me so base?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: No, I would not have you so base neither: but now and then, when you keep your chamber, you might let your footman out for eighteen pence a day, a great relief at years end I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: The age must needs be foul when vice reforms it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Nay, I've a greater quarrel to you yet.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'faith, what is't?

sp.speaker: Jewe.
sp.p: You made me believe at first the prince had you in great estimation, and would not offer to travail without you, nay, that he could not travail without your direction and intelligence.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'm sorry I said so i'faith, but sure I was overflown when I spoke it, I could ne'er ha' said it else.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Nay more, you swore to me, that you were the first that taught him to ride a great horse, and tread the ring with agility.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: By my troth I must needs confess I swore a great lie in that, and I was a villain to do it, for I could ne'er ride great horse in my life.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p:
Why lo, who would love you now but a citizen's wife? so inconstant, so for sworn: you say women are false creatures, but take away men, and they'd be honester than you — nay last of all, which offends me most of all, you told me you could countenance me at court, and you know we esteem a friend there, more
worth than a husband here.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What I spoke of that. Lady, I'll maintain.

sp.speaker: Iew:
sp.l: You maintain? you seen it court?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why by this diamond —

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: O take heed, you cannot have that, 'tis always in the eye of my husband.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I protest I will not keep it, but only use it for this virtue, as a token to fetch you, and approve my power, where you shall not only ye be received, but made known to the best and chiefest.

sp.speaker: Jewel.
sp.l: O are you true?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Let me lose my revenue else.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p: That's your word indeed, and upon that condition take it this kiss and my love for ever.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, I'll lead thee forth.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'm sick of all professions, my thoughts burn:
He travels best, that knows when to return.

div.stage: Enter knight, two officers after him.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Adieu, farewell, to bed you, I to my sweet citybird, my precious revenue, the very thought of a hundred and fifty angels, increases oil and spirit, ho:

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: I arrest you sir.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: You have made us wait a goodly time for you, have you not think you? you are in your rouses and mulwines a pox on you: and have no care of poor officers staying for you.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: I drunk but one health I protest, but I could void it now: at whose suit I pray?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: At the suit of him that makes suits, your tailor,

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Why, he made me the last, this, this that I wear

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p:
Argo, nay, we have been scholars I can tell you, we could not have been knaves so soon else, for as in that notable city called London, stand two most famous universities, poultry and Woodstreet, where some are of
twenty years standing, and have taken all their degrees from the master's side, down to the mistress side, the hole, so in like manner —

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Come, come, come, I had quite forgotten the hundred and fifty angels.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: 'Slid where be they?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: I'll bring you to the sight of 'em presently.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: A notable lad, and worthy to be arrested: we'll have but ten for waiting, and than thou shalt choose whether thou wilt run away from us, or we from thee.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: A match at running, come, come, follow me.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Nay, fear not that.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Peace, you may happen to see toys, but do not see 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Pah.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: That's the door.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: This? — knocks.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Sfoot officer you have spoiled all already?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p: Why? you shall see, you should have but whirled the ring once about, and there's a maid servant brought up to understand it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Who's at door?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: All's well again: phist, 'tis I, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: You, what are you?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Puh, where's thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Tell her one, she knows who, her pleasure's here, say.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Her pleasure? my mistress scorns to be without her pleasure at this time of night: is she so void of friends think you? take that for thinking so: a box

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: The hundred and fifty angels are locked up in a box, we shall not see 'em tonight.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.p:
How's this? am I used like a hundred pound
gentleman? Does my revenue forsake me? Damn me if ever I be her pleasure again. — well I must to prison.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Go prepare his room, there's no remedy, I'll bring him along, he's tame enough now.

sp.speaker: Knight
sp.l: Dare my tailor presume to use me in this sort?
He steals and I must lie in prison for't.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Come, come away sir.

div.stage: Enter a gentleman with a drawer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Art sure thou sawest him arrested drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: If mine eyes be sober.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And that's a question, mass here he goes, he shall not go to prison, I have a trick shall bail him — away.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Guess, guess, who am I? who am I?

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Who the devil are you? let go, — a pox on you, who are you? I have lost my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: Prisoner: I've mistaken, I cry you heartily mercy, I have done you infinite injury, a my troth I took you to be an honest man.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Where were your eyes? could you not see I was an officer, stop, stop, stop, stop.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ha, hah, hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Now phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now my lord.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Let princely blood
Nourish our hopes, we being confusion now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A terrible sudden blow.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I: what day is this hangs over us?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Byth' mass Monday.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: As I could wish my purpose will thrive best.
'Twas first my birthday, now my fortune's day,
I see whom fate will raise needs never pray.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: How is the air?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O full of trouble.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Does not the sky look piteously black

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: As if 'twere hung with rich men's consciences.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Ah, stuck not a comet like a Carbuncle
Upon the dreadful brow of twelve last night?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twelve, no 'twas about one.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: About one most proper, for that's the Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well shifted from thyself.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I could have wished it between one and two
His son and him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'll give you comfort then.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Prithee.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: There was a villainous raven seen last night,
Over the presence chamber in hard justle
With a young eglet.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: A raven! that was I, what did the raven?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Marry my lord the raven — to say truth,
I left the combat doubtful.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: So 'tis still,
For all is doubt, till the deed crown the will,
Now bless thy loins with freedom, wealth and honour,
Think all thy seed young lords, and by this act.
Make a foot-clothed posterity: now imagine
Thou seest thy daughters with their trains born up,
Whom else despised want, may curse to whoredom,
And public shames, which our state never threat,
She's never lewd, that is accounted great.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'll alter that court-axiom ▪ thus renewed,
She's never great, that is accounted lewd.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Stand close, the presence fills, here, here the place
And at his rising, let his fall be base,
Beneath thy foot.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How for his guard my lord?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: My gold and fear keeps with the chief of them

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That's rarely well.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.p: Bold heedless slave, that dares attempt a deed which shall in pieces rend him my lords both.

div.stage: Enter Lussurioso, and Infesto two lords.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: The happiness of the day.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Time my returning,
Treasons have still the worst, yet still are spurning.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: The Duke!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I ne'er was gladder to behold him.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: All. Long live your grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do not like that strain,
You know my age affords not to live long.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Spoken truer than you think for.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bestow that wish upon the prince our son.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: Nay, he's not to live long neither.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Him as the wealthy treasure of our hopes,
You as possession of our present comfort,
Both in one heart, we reverence in one.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O treason of a good complexion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now, what fresher news fills the court's ear?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Fidelio!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Glad tidings to your grace,
The prince is safe returned, and in your court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our joy breaks at our eyes, the prince is come!

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Soul quicking news — pale vengeance to my blood.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: By me presenting to your serious view,
A brief of all his travails.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis most welcome.
It shall be dear and precious to our eye.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: He reads, I'm glad her reads.
Now take thy opportunity, leave that place.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: At his first rising let his fall be base.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: That must be altered now.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Which? his rising or his fall?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Art thou dull now?
Thou hearest the prince is come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's here my lord?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have got such a large portion of knowledge, most worthy father, by the benefit of my travail,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: And so he has no doubt my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That I am bold now to warn you of lord
sp.p: Proditors insolent treason, who has irreligiously seduced a fellow, and closely conveyed him e'en in the presence-chair to murder you:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: O guilty, guilty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What was that fell? what's he?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am the man.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: O slave!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I have no power to strike,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I'm gone, I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let me admire heaven's wisdom in my son.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I confess it, he hired me —

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: This is slave,
'Tis forged against mine honour and my life,
For in what part of reason can't appear,
The prince being travailed should know treasons here
Plain counterfeit —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dost thou make false our son?

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: I know the prince will not affirm it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He can and will my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Most just, he may:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A guard.

sp.speaker: Luss.
sp.l: We cannot but in loyal zeal ourselves,
Lay hands on such a villain. —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay you, I find you here too.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: Us my lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Against Lussurioso and Infesto, who not only most riotously consume their houses in vicious gaming, mortgaging their livings to the merchant, whereby he with his heirs enter upon their lands, from whence this abuse comes, that in short time the son of the merchant has more lordships than the son of the nobleman (Which else was never born to inheritance) but that which is more impious, they most adulterously train out young ladies to midnight banquets, to the utter defamation of their own honours, and ridiculous abuse of their husbands.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: How could the prince hear that?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Most true my lord.
My conscience is a witness 'gainst itself,
For to that execution of chaste honour,
I was both hired and led.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.l: I hope the prince out of his plenteous wisdom
Will not give wrong to us: as for this fellow
He's poor, and cares not to be desperate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Justice my lord, I have my niece stolen from me
Sh'as left her dowry with me, but she's gone,
I'd rather have had her love then her money I,
This, this, is one of them, justice my lord:
I know him by his face, this is the thief.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Your grace may now in milder sense perceive
The wrong done to us by this impudent wretch,
Who has his hand fixed at the throat of law,
And therefore durst be desperate of his life,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Peace, you're too foul, your crime is in excess:
One spot of him, makes not your ulcers less.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Did your violence force away his niece?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: No my good lord; I'll still confess what's truth.
I did remove her from her many wrongs,
Which she was pleased to leave, they were so vild.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are you named?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Falso my lord, justice Falso, I'm known by that name.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Falso, you came fitly,
You are the very next that follows here.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I hope so my lord, my name is in all the records
I can assure your good grace.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Against justice Falso.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who having had the honest charge of his niece committed to his trust, by the last will and testament of her deceased father, and with her all the power of his wealth, not only against faith and conscience detains her dowry, but against nature and humanity assays to abuse her body.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I'm present to affirm it my loved lord.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: How? what make I here?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Either I must agree.
To loathed lust, or despised beggary.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are you the plaintive here?

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: I my good lord,
For fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Seldom comes a worse — and moreover not contained in this vice only, which is odious to much, but against the sacred use of justice, maintains three threeues to his men.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: Cuds me!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who only take purses in their master's liberty, where if any one chance to be taken, he appears before him in a false beard, and own of his own fellows takes his examination.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.l: By my troth as true as can be, but he shall not know on't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p:
And in the end will execute justice so cruelly upon him, that he will not trust him in a prison, but
commit him to his fellow's chamber.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Can a man do nothing i'the country but 'tis told at court? there's some busy informing knave abroad, a my life.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That this is true, and these, and more my lord.
(Be it under pardon spoken for mine own)
He the disease of justice, these of honour,
And this of loyalty and reverence:
The unswept venom of the palace,

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Slave!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Behold the prince to approve it.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: O, where?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Your eyes keep with your actions, both look wrong.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: An infernal to my spirit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My lord the prince:

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Tread me to dust, thou in whom wonder keeps,
Behold the serpent on his belly creeps.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Rankle not my foot, away.
Treason, we laugh at thy vain-labouring strings,
Above the foot thou hast no power o'er Kings

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot with sufficient joy receive thee,
And yet my joy's too much,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: My royal father,
To whose unnatural murder I was hired,
I thought it a more natural course of travail,
And answering future expectation,
To leave far countries, and inquire mine own,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To thee let reverence all her powers engage,
That art in youth a miracle to age.
State is but blindness, ethou hadst piercing art,
We only saw the knee; but thou the heart.
To thee then power and dukedom we resign,
▪ he's fit to reign, whose knowledge can refine:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Forbid it my obedience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our word's not vain,
I know thee wise canst both obey and reign,
The rest of life we dedicate to heaven.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A happy and safe reign to our new Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Without your prayers safer, and happier: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My royal lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Here take this diamond:
You know the virtue on't, it can fetch vice:
Madam Castiza:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: She attends my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Place a guard near us.
Know you you fellow lady?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My honours evil.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: Torment again?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So ugly are thy crimes,
Thine eye cannot endure 'em.
And that thy face may stand perpetually
Turned so from ours, and thy abhorred self,
Neither to threaten wrack of state or credit,
An everlasting banishment cease on thee.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: O fiend!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Thy life is such it is too bad to end.

sp.speaker: Proditor
sp.l: May thy rule, life, and all that's in thee glad,
Have as short time — as thy begetting had.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Away, thy curse is idle, the rest are under reformation, and therefore under pardon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our duties shall turn edge upon our crimes.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: 'Slid I was afraid of nothing, but that for my thievery, and bawdry I should have been turned to an innkeeper: my daughter, I am ashamed her worship should see me.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Who would not love a friend at court? what fine galleries and rooms am I brought through? I had thought my knight durst not have shown his face here, I.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Now mother of pride, and daughter of lust, which is your friend now?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'm sure you are not so unprovided to be without a friend here, you'll pay enough for him first.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: This is the worst room that ever I came in.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am your servant mistress, know you not me!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Your worship is too great for me to know: I'm but a small timbred-woman when I'm out of my apparel, and dare not venture upon greatness.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Do you deny me then? know you this purse?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: That purse? O death has the knight served me so? given away my favours?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stand forth — thou one of those, for whose close lusts the plague never leaves the city.
Thou worse than common: private, subtle harlot,
That dost deceive three with one feigned lip,
Thy husband, the world's eye, and the laws whip.
Thy zeal is hot, for 'tis to lust and fraud,
And dost not dread to make thy book thy bawd,
Thou'rt curse enough to husbands ill-got gains,
For whom the court rejects, his gold maintains:
How dear and rare was freedom wont to be,
Now few but are by their wife's copies free,
And brought to such a head that now we see,
City and suburbs wear one livery.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: 'Tis long of those, an't like your grace, that come in upon us, and will never leave marrying of our widows till they make 'em all as free as their first husbands.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I perceive you can shift a point well.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Let me have pardon I beseech your grace, and I'll peach 'em all, all the close women that are, and upon my knowledge there's above five thousand within the walls and the liberties.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: A band ▪ they shall be sent against the Turk, infidels against infidels.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I will hereafter live so modestly, I will not lie with mine own husband, nor come near a man in the way of honesty.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I'll be her warrant my lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You are deceived, you think you're still a justice.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, worse than I was before I kneeled, I am no justice now, I know I shall be some innkeeper at last.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My father! 'tis mine own father.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I should have wondered else, lust being so like.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Her birth was kin to mine, she may prove modest, for my sake I beseech you pardon her.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: For thy sake I'll do more, Fidelio hand her,
My favours on you both, next all that wealth
Which was committed to that perjures trust.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I'm a beggar now, worse than an innkeeper.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your mittimus shall not serve, I'll set myself free with a deliberandum, with a deliberandum, mark you:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's he? A guard!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Under your sufferance, worthy father,
His harm is to himself,
One that has loved vexation so much,
He cannot now be rid on't,
Has been so long in suits that he's law-mad.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A judgement, I crave a judgement, yea! Nunc pro tunc, corruption alicuius, I peeped me a raven in the face, and I thought it had been my solister: o the pens prick me.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: And here comes he (Wonder for temperance:)
Will take the cure upon him.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: A blessing to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Away, I'll have none on't, give me an audita querela, or a testificandum, or a dispatch in twelve terms, there's a blessing, there's a blessing.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You see the unbounded rage of his disease,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: 'Tis the foul fiend my lord has got within him the rest are fair to this, this breeds in ink,
sp.l: And to that colour turns the blood possessed,
For instance, now your grace shall see him dressed.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah hah I rejoice than he's puzzled ▪ and muzzled too is't come to a soepe corpus?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Ah, good sir, this is for want of patience.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: That's a fool.
She never saw the dogs and the bear's fight,
A country thing.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: This is for lack of grace,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I've other business, not so much idle time.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: You never say your prayers.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I'm, advised by my learned counsel,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The power of my charm come o'er thee,
Place by degrees thy wits before thee,
With silk en patience here I bind thee,
Not to move till I unwind thee.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Yea! is my cause so muddy? do I stick, do I stick (Fast?
Advocate here's my hand, pull, art made of flint?
Wilt not help out? — alas there's nothing in't.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: O do you sluice the vein now?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Yes my honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Pray let me see the issue.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: I therefore seek to keep it, — now burst out
Thou filthy stream of trouble, spite and doubt.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: O an extent, a proclamation, a summons, a recognizance, a tachment. and injunction, a writ, a seizure, a writ of praisement, an absolution, a quietus est.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You're quieter I hope by so much dregs.
Behold my lord:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: This, why it out frowns ink:

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: 'Tis the disease's nature, the fiend's drink.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: O sick, sick, signior Ply-fee, sick: lend me thy nightcap, o!

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The balsam of a temperate brain,
I pour into this thirsty vein,
And with this blessed oil of quiet,
Which is so cheap, that few men buy it,
Thy stormy temples I allay,
thou shalt give up the devil and prey,
Forsake his works, the'yre foul and black,
And keep thee bare in purse and back.
No more shalt thou in paper quarrel,
To dress up apes in good apparel.
He throws his stock, and all his flock,
Into a swallowing gulf,
That sends his goose unto his fox,
His lamb unto his wolf.
Keep thy increase,
And live at peace,
For war's not equal to this battle,
That eats but men this men and cat-tail,
Therefore no more this combat choose:
Where he that wins, does always lose,
And those that gain all, with this curse receive it,
From fools they get it, to their sons they leave it.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Haile sacred patience, I begin to feel
sp.p: I have a conscience now, truth in my words, compassion in my heart, and above all, in my blood peace's music,
sp.l: Use me how you can,
You shall find me an honest-quiet man.
O, pardon, that I dare behold that face,
"Now I've least law, I hope have most grace,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: We both admire the workman and his piece:
Thus when all hearts are tuned to honour's strings,
There is no music to the choir of Kings.

div.head: Prologus
div.l: The marks and notions extant in each spirit,
Sealed by th'industrious hand of art and merit,
Methinks appear transparent (As the mind
By fence were bounded and might seem confined
In th' external eye) nor shall our tragic muse,
(If strong hope fail not) need a coined excuse
But to those marginal notes of yours do bring
(In following numbers from the learned spring)
Matter instructive to enrich their parts
Where knowledge reigns crowned with it own deserts,
Let such with serious and impartial hearing
Sound sense, quick sight and judgement never erring:
Survey and censure the minerval frame
Of his elaborate work: and if his name
Merit regard, and you vouchsafe to grace him
With eminent love, or mongst those laureates place him,
That with the magic of sweet poesy,
Transfer Parnassus into Brittany,
He shall digest the chaos of his brain,
To tuneful order and acquire a strain,
Near to the music of the heavenly spheres,
To fit times guard and ravish choicest ears.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: Fame and opinion like the two winged cap
On Hermes head, do lift all poets up:
Some, though deserving, yet above the sphere
Of true impartial censure, whose tuned ear
Listens to all and can with judgement say,
Others sing well, though Thracian Orpheus play.
Our muse affects no excellence: if fame tell
And through her shrill trump at the muses well
(Where the thrice trebled bench of learning sits
In strict examination of others wits)
Sound ours, though humbly strains, whose infant growth
Nor dares, nor will, with times hugged darlings quarrel,
Nor stand the lightning with the sacred laurel)
We rest content: yet thus far may conceit
Carry each labouring artist, where the weight
Of his oyld task is over, that his tongue
May like a father of his tender young
Speak natures language and not be withstood,
When with our muse he saith, that this is good.

div.p: This epilogue should have been printed at the end of the book, but there was no spare place for it.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
